subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range: Understanding Linear Transformations
contentHtml:
A linear transformation is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that maps one vector space to another.

The kernel (or null space) of a transformation consists of all vectors that are mapped to the zero vector. This is equivalent to finding the solution set to the equation T(x) = 0, where T is the transformation and x is an input vector.

intuition: Think of the kernel as the set of 'zero vectors' that, when transformed, result in a zero output. This is useful for understanding how transformations preserve certain properties.

realWorldApplications: In machine learning, understanding the kernel of a transformation can help identify features that are not contributing to the model's performance.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range: Understanding Linear Transformations
contentHtml:
A linear transformation is a crucial concept in linear algebra that describes how vectors are mapped to new vectors under some operation.

The kernel of a transformation is the set of all inputs that get sent to the zero vector, while its range is the set of all possible outputs. Think of it like a filter: the kernel represents the noise that gets eliminated, and the range represents the desired signal.
intuition: The kernel represents the 'null space' of the transformation, where all inputs get mapped to zero. The range represents the 'column space', which is the set of all possible outputs.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, understanding the kernel and range of a linear transformation helps in designing effective feature extractors and dimensionality reduction techniques.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse the kernel with the null space; they're not the same thing. The kernel is specific to the transformation, while the null space is a property of the matrix representation.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range: Understanding Linear Transformations
contentHtml:
A linear transformation is a way to change one vector space into another by multiplying each element in the original space by a matrix.

The kernel (or null space) of a linear transformation is the set of all vectors that, when transformed, result in the zero vector. The range (or column space) is the set of all possible output vectors.
intuition: Think of the kernel as the 'zero vector' of the transformation, and the range as the set of all possible outputs. This concept is crucial in machine learning, where we often work with linear transformations to map inputs to outputs.
realWorldApplications: In neural networks, the kernel represents the set of all input vectors that result in the same output, while the range represents the set of all possible outputs.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse the kernel and range – they're not the same thing!

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range of Linear Transformations
contentHtml:
The kernel and range of a linear transformation are fundamental concepts in linear algebra.

The kernel, also known as the null space, is the set of all vectors that map to the zero vector under the transformation. The range, also known as the column space or image, is the set of all possible outputs or values taken by the transformation.
intuition: Understanding the kernel and range of a linear transformation is crucial for many applications in machine learning, such as finding the null space of a matrix or projecting data onto a lower-dimensional subspace.
realWorldApplications: Finding the null space of a matrix

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: ℝ³ → ℝ² defined by the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\ -1 & 3\end{bmatrix}\].

",
hints: Think about the null space of A.
The image of T is a subspace of ℝ². What can you say about its dimension?
Use the fact that the range of T is equal to the column space of A.
solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, we need to solve the equation Ax = 0.

  • We can rewrite this as \[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\ -1 & 3\end{bmatrix}\]x = 0

This is equivalent to the system of equations:

  • 1x + 2y - z = 0
  • -x + 3y = 0

Solving this, we get that x = y = z = 0 is a solution.

The range of T is equal to the column space of A. We can find the columns of A:

  • \[\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ -1\end{bmatrix}\]
  • \[\begin{bmatrix}2 \\ 3\end{bmatrix}\]

The span of these vectors is the column space, which has dimension 2.

",
answerShort: The kernel is {(0, 0, 0)}, and the range is ℝ²." },

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: ℝ² → ℝ³ defined by the matrix A =
\[ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \].",
hints: Consider the null space of A.
Think about the span of its columns.
solutionHtml:
Step 1: Find the kernel.

We can do this by solving the system of equations:

\[ \begin{align*} x + 0y &= 0 \\ 2x + y &= 0 \end{align*} \]

This has a unique solution, so the kernel is trivial.

Step 2: Find the range.

The image of T is the set of all vectors that can be written as Ax for some x in ℝ². Since A has two columns, its image is at most 2-dimensional.

We can find a basis for this space by solving the system:

\[ \begin{align*} 1x + 0y &= z_1 \\ 0x + 1y &= z_2 \end{align*} \]

This has a solution, so the range is 2-dimensional.

",

statementHtml:

",
hints: The kernel is the set of all vectors that, when transformed, result in the zero vector.
Start by computing the null space of A.
Use this to find the range of T.
solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, compute the null space of A:

\

\[K = ext{null}(A) = \left\{ egin{pmatrix}x\ y\end{pmatrix}\in ℝ²: egin{pmatrix}1 & 2\ -1 & 3\end{pmatrix} egin{pmatrix}x\ y\end{pmatrix} = egin{pmatrix}0\ 0\end{pmatrix} ight\}\]

\

The solution is x + 2y = 0, so the kernel is spanned by \[ egin{pmatrix}-2\ 1\end{pmatrix}\].

\

To find the range, compute the column space of A:

\

\[R = ext{col}(A) = \left\{ egin{pmatrix}x_1\ x_2\end{pmatrix}: egin{pmatrix}1 & 2\ -1 & 3\end{pmatrix} egin{pmatrix}a_{11} & a_{12}\ a_{21} & a_{22}\end{pmatrix} = egin{pmatrix}x_1\ x_2\end{pmatrix} ight\}\]

\

The solution is the set of all vectors of the form \[ egin{pmatrix}a + 3b\ -a + b\end{pmatrix}\], where a, b are real numbers.

",
answerShort:
The kernel is spanned by \[\begin{pmatrix}-2\\ 1\end{pmatrix}\] and the range is the set of all vectors of the form \[\begin{pmatrix}a + 3b\\ -a + b\end{pmatrix}\].

" },

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: ℝ3 → ℝ2

defined by the matrix \[A = \\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\\\ -1 & 1 \\end{bmatrix}\].

",
hints: The kernel is the set of all vectors that, when transformed, result in the zero vector.
Start by finding a basis for the range.
Use this basis to find the matrix representation of T.
solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, we need to solve the system of equations:

\[\begin{align*} x + 2y &= 0 \\ -x + y &= 0 \end{align*}\]

This has a solution \[(1, -1)^T\]. Since this is the only solution, we have found the kernel.

To find the range, we need to find the image of the standard basis vectors:

\[\begin{align*} \text{Im}(e_1) &= Ae_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \\ \text{Im}(e_2) &= Ae_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}. \end{align*}\]

A basis for the range is then \[(3, -1)^T, (2, 1)^T\].

statementHtml: Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation A: ℝ3 → ℝ2, where A = \[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 \\ -1 & 0\end{bmatrix}\].",

Consider the image of A under different inputs. How do these relate to the range?
Use the fact that the rank-nullity theorem applies to A
solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, we set Ax = 0 and solve for x. This gives us the system of equations:

  • x + 2y = 0
  • -x = 0

Solving this, we find that the kernel is spanned by (1,-1).

To find the range, we can use the fact that it's equal to the column space of A. We can do this by finding the basis vectors for the column space:

  • \[\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ -1\end{bmatrix}\]

This shows that the range is spanned by these two vectors.

problem.statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3 defined by

  • T([x, y]) = [x, y, x + y]
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the kernel, we need to solve T(x) = [0, 0, 0].

  1. Let T([x, y]) = [0, 0, 0]. Then x + y = 0.
  2. This is a linear equation in two variables. The solution set is the line y = -x.
  3. The kernel is spanned by this line.

contentHtml:
In linear algebra, we often encounter linear transformations between vector spaces.

Given a transformation T: V → W, our goal is to understand its kernel (null space) and range (image).
name: Linear Transformation" },
statementHtml:
Consider the linear transformation T: ℝ² → ℝ³ defined by

\[\begin{bmatrix}T_1\\T_2\\T_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix}\]. Find the kernel and range of T.

",
hints: Hint: Use the transformation matrix to find the null space
solutionHtml:
Step 1: Compute the null space

\[\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} \in \ker T \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}\]

Step 2: Find the null space

\[\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} \in \ker T \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad x + y = 0\]

Step 3: Compute the range

\[T(\mathbf{v}) = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x \\ y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}x + y \\ x + y \\ (x+y) + y\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}2(x+y) \\ 2(x+y) \\ 3(x+y)\end{bmatrix}\]

Step 4: Find the range

\[T(\mathbf{v}) = \begin{bmatrix}2x \\ 2x \\ 3x\end{bmatrix}, x \in ℝ\]

",
answerShort: The kernel is the set of vectors satisfying \(x + y = 0\), and the range is the set of vectors of the form \(\begin{bmatrix}2x \\ 2x \\ 3x\end{bmatrix}\)" },

subject: linear_algebra
title: Kernel and Range: Understanding Linear Transformations
contentHtml: In linear algebra, a linear transformation is a function that preserves vector addition and scalar multiplication.

problem.statementHtml:
Find the kernel and range of the linear transformation T: \mathbb{R}^2 → \mathbb{R}^3 defined by:

  • A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix}
hints: Hint: Find the null space and column space of A
problem.solutionHtml:
Step 1: Compute the determinant of A.

  • \[\det(A) = (1)(1) - (0)(0) = 1\]

Why? We compute the determinant to find the volume scaling factor for the transformation.
problem.answerShort: The kernel is span{<math>(1, 0)</math>} and the range is \mathbb{R}^3

steps.explanation: We compute the determinant to find the volume scaling factor for the transformation.

steps.description: Find the null space of A
steps.explanation: The null space contains all vectors that are mapped to zero.

steps.description: Find the column space of A
steps.explanation: The column space contains all linear combinations of the columns of A.

steps.description: Determine if T is injective or surjective
steps.mathHtml: \[T\text{ is not injective since } (1, 0) \mapsto (1, 0), but it is surjective since the range is \mathbb{R}^3\]
steps.explanation: We check if T is one-to-one and onto.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The kernel is span{<math>(1, 0)</math>} and the range is \mathbb{R}^3
